awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Interpersonal Coordination and Coregulation during Collaborative Problem Solving
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative problem solving (CPS) is an essential skill in our increasingly connected and globalized world. Yet, there is a paucity of knowledge on how to define, measure, and develop this skill, especially in the context of STEM learning. A team of investigators from Notre Dame University, Florida State University, and Arizona State University will seek to discover how interpersonal interactions arise and influence CPS processes and outcomes in digital STEM learning environments. The research will focus on groups of high school and college students collaborating virtually within a STEM educational game called Physics Playground. The hypothesis is that CPS effectiveness can be improved by providing real-time automated feedback on the ongoing collaboration. The investigators will collect an array of data, ranging from individual physiological measures to learning outcome measures to group communication patterns. Their goal is to improve the design of future CPS learning environments, making them more enjoyable, engaging, and effective. The project is funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports work that advances the fundamental research literature on STEM learning.

The research will involve dyads and triads collaborating virtually within a learning environment called Physics Playground, a STEM educational game. Data will be collected in both the lab and classroom, using a diverse sample of high school and college students from three sites across the U.S. The team will integrate data from a range of sources including modeling of small group problem solving and collaborative learning and from the modeling of low-level data from eye tracking, facial feature tracking, psychophysiology, and linguistic/paralinguistic speech analysis. Additionally, the team will study the moderating effects of task constraints and group composition on CPS processes and outcomes. A further goal is to model dynamic CPS processes using nonlinear time series analyses and multimodal deep recurrent neural networks. The computational models will be integrated into the learning environment to test the hypothesis that CPS outcomes can be improved by providing automated feedback on unfolding collaborative processes. Thus, by blending basic experimental research, multisensor-multimodal analysis, computational modeling, and dynamic computerized intervention, the researchers will attempt to make foundational theoretical, methodological, and technological advances.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
The foundational goal of this project is to gain fundamental knowledge on how interpersonal interactions influence the processes and outcomes of collaborative problem solving (CPS) in digital STEM learning environments. Our key hypothesis is that CPS is fundamentally about communication and coordination among people, involving a host of low-level socio-cognitive processes, such as conversational grounding, joint attention, and emotional coregulation that interact at multiple time scales to functionally support higher-level processes, such as effective communication and activate participation. We conducted our research within the context of triads virtually collaborating within STEM learning environments (i.e., an educational game called Physics Playground and Minecraft), collecting data from both the lab and classrooms using a diverse sample of middle-school and college students from three sites across the U.S.

We completed 32 integrative research activities resulting in the following intellectual contributions:

  1. We developed and empirically validated a generalizable collaborative problem solving framework. In addition to providing the foundational theoretical grounding for the current project, the framework is also being widely used in other projects, most significantly the NSF National Artificial Institute for Student-AI Teaming (www.isat.ai).
  2. We collected two large multimodal, multiparty datasets featuring triads engaging in remote CPS. Available channels include eye gaze, physiology, body movements, facial expressions, speech, language, log files, coded CPS behaviors, CPS outcomes, self-report questionnaires, and individual difference measures. These datasets will be disseminated to the research community.
  3. Our studies revealed how task constraints and individual differences in group composition moderate collaborative processes and CPS outcomes. We also identified the key collaborative behaviors and patterns that predict CPS outcomes.
  4. We applied nonlinear dynamical systems techniques (multimodal recurrence quantification analysis), network-based modeling (multilevel vector autoregression), and deep machine learning (recurrent neural networks) to identify complex intra- and inter-individual patterns in CPS behaviors and how they unfold over time.
  5. We developed multimodal, multiparty machine learning techniques to automatically measure CPS behaviors and outcomes from unimodal (mainly language and eye gaze) and multimodal signals (facial expressions, acoustic-prosodic cues, language, eye gaze, task context) in a manner that generalizes across individuals and domains. 
  6. We designed semi-automated interventions aimed at improving CPS outcomes by providing objective model-based feedback on CPS skills. We conducted two user studies to investigate whether these interventions resulted in improved CPS skills.. 

We disseminated our findings in 25 peer-reviewed publications, two book chapters, non-archival conference presentations, invited keynotes, and invited talks/panels. Our work received or was a finalist for three best paper awards at international conferences with students as lead authors on two of the papers (#1 and #3 below):

  1. Finalist for Best Paper Award. Pugh, S. L., Rao, A., Stewart, A. E., & D'Mello, S. K. (2022). Do Speech-Based Collaboration Analytics Generalize Across Task Contexts? Proceedings of the 12th International Learning Analytics and Knowledge Conference (LAK 22).
  2. Best Full Paper Award. Vrzakova, H., Amon, M. J., Stewart, A., Duran, N., & D'Mello, S. K. (2020). Focused or Stuck Together: Multimodal Patterns Reveal Triads? Performance in Collaborative Problem Solving. Proceedings of the International Conference on Learning Analytics & Knowledge (LAK 20)
  3. Best Student Paper Award (2019). Eloy, L., Stewart, A., Amon, M., Reindhardt, C., Michaels, A., Sun, C., Shute, V., Duran, N., & D'Mello, S. K. Modeling Team-level Multimodal Dynamics during Multiparty Collaboration. Proceedings of the 21st ACM International Conference on Multimodal Interaction (ICMI 2019).

We also made the following broader impacts:

  • With respect to interdisciplinary training, the project has supported training of five postdoctoral researchers, six graduate students, more than ten undergraduate students, and multiple research staff. Students were trained in the interdisciplinary fields of computer science, cognitive psychology, and the learning sciences. The project supported one PhD dissertation, one more is in progress, and some of the undergraduate students who participated in the research are now enrolled in graduate school. 
  • With respect to broadening participation of underrepresented groups in science, the project supported the dissertation of one of the few Black women to earn a Computer Science PhD in 2020 (this student subsequently completed a postdoctoral fellowship at Carnegie Mellon University and will begin a tenure-track position at the University of Pittsburgh in Fall 2022). In addition, the project supported a female postdoctoral researcher towards obtaining a tenure-track position at the University of Florida.
  • Finally, the project has also benefited society through its emphasis on collaborative problem solving in the context of STEM learning. The Partnership for 21st Century Learning (P21) has recognized collaboration as one of the essential learning and innovation skills to prepare students for future challenges in work and life. By directly focusing on a key collaboration skill in the context of STEM learning environments, the project makes a direct contribution to society by advancing fundamental knowledge on how to train the 21set century workforce to acquire skills required to meet the challenges of the future.

Last Modified: 07/19/2022
Modified by: Sidney D'mello

por.por_txt_cntn:
The foundational goal of this project is to gain fundamental knowledge on how interpersonal interactions influence the processes and outcomes of collaborative problem solving (CPS) in digital STEM learning environments. Our key hypothesis is that CPS is fundamentally about communication and coordination among people, involving a host of low-level socio-cognitive processes, such as conversational grounding, joint attention, and emotional coregulation that interact at multiple time scales to functionally support higher-level processes, such as effective communication and activate participation. We conducted our research within the context of triads virtually collaborating within STEM learning environments (i.e., an educational game called Physics Playground and Minecraft), collecting data from both the lab and classrooms using a diverse sample of middle-school and college students from three sites across the U.S.
We completed 32 integrative research activities resulting in the following intellectual contributions:

We developed and empirically validated a generalizable collaborative problem solving framework. In addition to providing the foundational theoretical grounding for the current project, the framework is also being widely used in other projects, most significantly the NSF National Artificial Institute for Student-AI Teaming (www.isat.ai).

We applied nonlinear dynamical systems techniques (multimodal recurrence quantification analysis), network-based modeling (multilevel vector autoregression), and deep machine learning (recurrent neural networks) to identify complex intra- and inter-individual patterns in CPS behaviors and how they unfold over time. 
We developed multimodal, multiparty machine learning techniques to automatically measure CPS behaviors and outcomes from unimodal (mainly language and eye gaze) and multimodal signals (facial expressions, acoustic-prosodic cues, language, eye gaze, task context) in a manner that generalizes across individuals and domains.

We disseminated our findings in 25 peer-reviewed publications, two book chapters, non-archival conference presentations, invited keynotes, and invited talks/panels. Our work received or was a finalist for three best paper awards at international conferences with students as lead authors on two of the papers (#1 and #3 below):

Finalist for Best Paper Award. Pugh, S. L., Rao, A., Stewart, A. E., & D'Mello, S. K. (2022). Do Speech-Based Collaboration Analytics Generalize Across Task Contexts? Proceedings of the 12th International Learning Analytics and Knowledge Conference (LAK 22).

Best Student Paper Award (2019). Eloy, L., Stewart, A., Amon, M., Reindhardt, C., Michaels, A., Sun, C., Shute, V., Duran, N., & D'Mello, S. K. Modeling Team-level Multimodal Dynamics during Multiparty Collaboration. Proceedings of the 21st ACM International Conference on Multimodal Interaction (ICMI 2019). 

We also made the following broader impacts:

With respect to interdisciplinary training, the project has supported training of five postdoctoral researchers, six graduate students, more than ten undergraduate students, and multiple research staff. Students were trained in the interdisciplinary fields of computer science, cognitive psychology, and the learning sciences. The project supported one PhD dissertation, one more is in progress, and some of the undergraduate students who participated in the research are now enrolled in graduate school.

The Partnership for 21st Century Learning (P21) has recognized collaboration as one of the essential learning and innovation skills to prepare students for future challenges in work and life. By directly focusing on a key collaboration skill in the context of STEM learning environments, the project makes a direct contribution to society by advancing fundamental knowledge on how to train the 21set century workforce to acquire skills required to meet the challenges of the future.
